guide.introduction:
I'll demonstrate how to turn a raster image into a G-Code engraving pattern with GIMP, Inkscape, Pycam and EMC2 in Ubuntu Linux. The steps are covered in detail in this video:

Open Source CNC Toolpathing Workflow.
guide.introduction_rendered:
I'll demonstrate how to turn a raster image into a G-Code engraving pattern with GIMP, Inkscape, Pycam and EMC2 in Ubuntu Linux. The steps are covered in detail in this video:

Open Source CNC Toolpathing Workflow.

Tools
  • Computer running Linux

lines.text: Install the necessary software:
lines.text_raw: Install the necessary software:

lines.text: Ubuntu Linux/EMC2
lines.text_raw: [http://linuxcnc.org/|Ubuntu Linux/EMC2]

lines.text: GIMP
lines.text_raw: [http://www.gimp.org/|GIMP]

lines.text: Pycam
lines.text_raw: [http://pycam.sourceforge.net/|Pycam]

lines.text: Inkscape
lines.text_raw: [http://www.inkscape.org/|Inkscape]

lines.text: In GIMP, open an image.
lines.text_raw: In GIMP, open an image.

lines.text: Edit as you like, then apply a threshold (Colors->Threshold) to make a black-and-white only (not greyscale) image.
lines.text_raw: Edit as you like, then apply a threshold (Colors->Threshold) to make a black-and-white only (not greyscale) image.

lines.text: Save the image.
lines.text_raw: Save the image.

lines.text: In Inkscape, create a new file that reflects the size of your CNC work area.
lines.text_raw: In Inkscape, create a new file that reflects the size of your CNC work area.

lines.text: Import the image created in the previous step.
lines.text_raw: Import the image created in the previous step.

lines.text: Use the Trace Bitmap function (Path->Trace Bitmap) to create a vector outline of the raster image.
lines.text_raw: Use the Trace Bitmap function (Path->Trace Bitmap) to create a vector outline of the raster image.

lines.text: Delete the imported raster image, leaving only the vector tracing.
lines.text_raw: Delete the imported raster image, leaving only the vector tracing.

lines.text: Save the file as an .SVG
lines.text_raw: Save the file as an .SVG

lines.text: Open the SVG in Pycam.
lines.text_raw: Open the SVG in Pycam.

lines.text: Edit Pycam preferences:
lines.text_raw: Edit Pycam preferences:

lines.text: Under General, set the units to inches.
lines.text_raw: Under General, set the units to inches.

lines.text: Under Gcode, set the safety height to 1 inch.
lines.text_raw: Under Gcode, set the safety height to 1 inch.

lines.text: Adjust the tool parameters for the default cylindrical tool.
lines.text_raw: Adjust the tool parameters for the default cylindrical tool.

lines.text: Diameter = 0.125"; Feed Rate = 75 inches/minute (this may vary depending on your CNC)
lines.text_raw: Diameter = 0.125"; Feed Rate = 75 inches/minute (this may vary depending on your CNC)

lines.text: Under Tasks, activate only the Gravure/Tracing task. Make these adjustments:
lines.text_raw: Under Tasks, activate only the Gravure/Tracing task. Make these adjustments:

lines.text: Tool = Cylindrical; Process = Gravure/Tracing
lines.text_raw: Tool = Cylindrical; Process = Gravure/Tracing

lines.text: Generate the G-Code by clicking Generate Toolpath.
lines.text_raw: Generate the G-Code by clicking Generate Toolpath.

lines.text: Under Toolpaths, export as an .ngc file.
lines.text_raw: Under Toolpaths, export as an .ngc file.

lines.text: Your G-Code is ready to run!
lines.text_raw: Your G-Code is ready to run!

guide.summary: An overview of toolpathing for the DIYLILCNC (or any 3-axis CNC) using 100% free & open-source software.
